Description: Small ovoid jar of marl pottery with a small flat base, ledge rim and two pierced cylindrical handles on the shoulder; decorated in red-brown paint on each side with a series of horizontal lines that dip in the centre (the so-called broken line motif). The handles are painted with horizontal lines, below them is a fan-shaped bush motif. The base has a spiral; the rim top is painted but the design is unclear.
Curator's comments: The broken line motif has been interpreted to represent some sort of light architecture. See discussion in: G. Graff, M. Eyckerman & S. Hendrickx, Architectural elements on Decorated pottery and the ritual presentation of desert animals, in: R. Friedman & P.N. Fiske (eds), Egypt At its origins3. Orientalia Lovaniensia Analecta 205, Leuven (2011), pp. 448–451. Like Decorated ware D15 in Petrie’s Corpus of Prehistoric Pottery (1921)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
